member.name: T:Accenture.Security.Eso.Web.DevSignOn.Users.EnterpriseAuthenticationUserReader
member.summary:
Reads an XML file of users to build up custom enterprise identities for authentication.
The xml file can contain: Users with user names, passwords, and custom data, Blocks of users to easily generate authentication information for large quantities of users when needed for testing, and Templates with simple string concatenation templates to easily re-use and build up a user.
member.example: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <Security> <Templates> <!-- Defines a template, all templates are required to have a unique name attribute --> <Template name="user"> <!-- Expression are just string replacement using syntax of ${ [field name] } --> <!-- Defines an expression that sets the SapUserId field to the value of the PeopleKey field --> <sapUserId>${peopleKey}</userId> <!-- Defines an expression that sets the DisplayName field to the value --> <displayName>${lastName}, ${firstName} ${middleInitial}</displayName> <enterpriseId>${firstName}.${lastName}</enterpriseId> <emailAddress>${firstName}.${lastName}@accenture.com</emailAddress> <!-- Adds a value of MyApp.Users to the MultiValue groups key --> <groups> <group>MyApp.Users</group> </groups> </Template> <!-- Defines a second template named admin, that mixes in the template definition from users. Multiple templates can be mixed in, separate the template names with a semi-colon (;) --> <Template name="admin" templates="user"> <!-- Any users using this template will belong to both the MyApp.Users and MyApp.Admins groups --> <groups> <group>MyApp.Admins</group> </groups> </Template> </Templates> <UserBlocks> <!-- User Blocks define large sets of users quickly, at run time the blocks will be expanded into unique sets of users. This is very useful for generating large quantities of users for load testing. --> <UserBlock name="APT" id-start="1000" count="1000"> <!-- When expanding expression user blocks get a special value named 'id' which is incremented by 1 from id-start --> <UserName>aptuser${id}</UserName> <!-- Expression will be expanded to create user names aptuser1000, aptuser1001, ... aptuser1999 --> <Password>password${id}</Password> <!-- Expression will be expanded to create passwords password1000, password1001, ... password1999 --> <Identity templates="user"> <!-- define the custom data, mixing in the default user template --> <!-- Define some custom expression so when the 'user' template is mixed in, those expression will have valid values. --> <firstName>User ${id}</firstName> <lastName>APT</lastName> <peopleKey>${id}</peopleKey> </Identity> </UserBlock> </UserBlocks> <Users> <!-- The most convential way to define users for testing is to just create them individually --> <!-- A user must have a name and password attribute with a constant value, they cannot be expressions --> <User name="user1" password="password1"> <!-- The Identity element is where you put all your custom data, it takes an optional attribute named 'templates' that is a semi-colon separated list of template names that can be mixed in --> <Identity templates="user"> <firstName>John</firstName> <lastName>Doe</lastName> <middleInitial>J</middleInitial> <peopleKey>1</peopleKey> </Identity> </User> <User name="admin2" password="admin2"> <!-- The Identity element is where you put all your custom data, it takes an optional attribute named 'templates' that is a semi-colon separated list of template names that can be mixed in --> <Identity templates="admin"> <firstName>John</firstName> <lastName>Admin</lastName> <middleInitial>J</middleInitial> <peopleKey>2</peopleKey> </Identity> </User> </Users> </Security>
